Title: Any two positive integers are co-prime if their sum is a prime number
Content: Any two positive integers are co-prime if their sum is a prime number Is this a trivial thing to say? I have a proof, but I don't want to bore anyone if it's just a trivial matter-of-fact thing about primes and co-primes.
AcceptedAnswer: When both integers are positive, this is a special case of the converse to Bézout's theorem (labeled (ii) on the linked page). If $a+b=p$, that theorem (with $x=y=1$) tells us that $\gcd(a,b)$ must be a divisor of $p$. But if $p$ is prime, that means $\gcd(a,b)$ is either $p$ or $1$. Moreover, if $a$ and $b$ are both positive, then $a+b=p$ implies that $a$ and $b$ are both smaller than $p$, so they cannot have $p$ as a divisor. So $\gcd(a,b)=1$.
